keyStats.giniTooltip: The Gini coefficient measures income inequality on a scale from 0 to 1. A value of 0 represents perfect equality (everyone has the same income), while 1 represents maximum inequality (one person has all the income). Higher values indicate greater inequality. Brazil typically scores around 0.52-0.53, placing it among the most unequal countries in the world.

wealth.title: Wealth Concentration
wealth.description: Analysis of wealth distribution in Brazil, including millionaire and billionaire populations.
wealth.measurementNotesText: Wealth estimates follow Global Wealth Report methodology and are less precise than income statistics. "Net worth" refers to total assets minus debts. Millionaire thresholds are defined in US dollars (USD) at market exchange rates (not PPP).

wealthInequality.title: Wealth Inequality
wealthInequality.wealthGiniDefinition: The Gini coefficient measures wealth inequality on a scale from 0 to 1. A value of 0 represents perfect equality (everyone has the same wealth), while 1 represents maximum inequality (one person has all the wealth). Wealth inequality is typically much higher than income inequality because wealth accumulates over time and can be inherited. Brazil's wealth Gini is around 0.85, indicating extreme concentration of assets.
wealthInequality.comparison: Wealth inequality is significantly higher than income inequality (Gini: {{gini}})

millionairePopulation.populationHolds: {{percent}}% of the population holds {{wealth}}% of wealth

billionairePopulation.title: Billionaire Population
billionairePopulation.notesText: Billionaires are defined as individuals with net worth of at least US$ 1B (USD). Combined wealth is estimated at about US$ {{wealth}}B in {{year}}.
billionairePopulation.context: Brazil ranks among the top 10 countries by billionaire count globally. The combined wealth of Brazilian billionaires exceeds the annual income of the poorest 50% of the population.

wealthGapVisualized.title: The Wealth Gap Visualized
wealthGapVisualized.description: Just {{percent}}% of Brazilians (millionaires) control nearly half of all wealth, while 99.8% of the population shares the remaining half.

methodology.title: Methodology & Sources
methodology.description: Complete source catalog and data quality information.
methodology.dataCurrencyText: Data reflects 2023–2024 statistics, with noted exceptions. BRL values are shown as R$; poverty lines are also shown in US$ (2017 PPP). Wealth thresholds (millionaires/billionaires) use USD at market exchange rates (not PPP).

dataQuality.title: Data Quality
knownLimitationsItems: Wealth data relies heavily on surveys and may undercount hidden assets
Regional poverty figures may not capture within-region urban/rural differences
Racial categories follow Brazilian census classifications and may not match other countries' groupings
Informal sector income is difficult to measure accurately
PPP conversion introduces uncertainty in international comparisons
